text:
3.11 First fundamental form

Definition 69: First fundamental formLet \(\mathcal{S}\) be a regular surface and \(\mathbf{p}\in \mathcal{S}\). The first fundamental form of \(\mathcal{S}\) at \(\mathbf{p}\) is the bilinear symmetric map \[
I_{\mathbf{p}} \colon T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\times T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\to \mathbb{R}\,, \quad I_{\mathbf{p}} (\mathbf{v},\mathbf{w}) := \mathbf{v}\cdot \mathbf{w}\,.
\]



Definition 70: Coordinate functions on tangent planeLet \({\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U \to \mathbb{R}^3\) be a regular chart of \(\mathcal{S}\). For each \(\mathbf{p}\in {\pmb{\sigma}}(U)\) we have \[
T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}= \operatorname{span} \{{\pmb{\sigma}}_u,{\pmb{\sigma}}_v\} \,,
\] where \({\pmb{\sigma}}_u\) and \({\pmb{\sigma}}_v\) are evaluated at the point \((u,v) \in U\) such that \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(u,v)=\mathbf{p}\,.
\] Therefore, for each \(\mathbf{v}\in T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\), there exist \(\lambda,\mu \in \mathbb{R}\) such that \[
\mathbf{v}= \lambda {\pmb{\sigma}}_u + \mu {\pmb{\sigma}}_v \,.
\] The coordinate functions on \(T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\) are the linear maps \[
du, dv \colon T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\to \mathbb{R}\,, \quad du(\mathbf{v}) := \lambda \,,  
\quad dv(\mathbf{v}) := \mu \,.
\]



Definition 71: First fundamental form of a chartLet \({\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U \to \mathbb{R}^3\) be a regular chart of \(\mathcal{S}\). Define the functions \[
E , F , G \colon U \to \mathbb{R}
\] by setting \[
E := {\pmb{\sigma}}_u \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_u \,, \quad  F := {\pmb{\sigma}}_u \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_v \,, \quad
G := {\pmb{\sigma}}_v \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_v \,.
\] The first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is the quadratic form \[
\mathscr{F}_1 \colon T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\to \mathbb{R}
\] defined by \[
\mathscr{F}_1 (\mathbf{v}) := E \, du^2(\mathbf{v}) + 2F \, du(\mathbf{v}) \, dv (\mathbf{v})+ G \, dv^2 (\mathbf{v}) \,,
\] for all \(\mathbf{v}\in T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\), and \(\mathbf{p}\in {\pmb{\sigma}}(U)\), where \(E,F,G\) are evaluated at \[
(u,v) = {\pmb{\sigma}}^{-1}(\mathbf{p}) \,.
\]



Theorem 72Let \({\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U \to \mathbb{R}^3\) be a regular chart of \(\mathcal{S}\), and \(\mathbf{p}\in {\pmb{\sigma}}(U)\). Then \[
I_{\mathbf{p}} (\mathbf{v},\mathbf{w}) = (du (\mathbf{v}), dv(\mathbf{v}) )  \,
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
E & F \\
F & G
\end{array}
\right) \, (du(\mathbf{w}) , dv(\mathbf{w}))^T \,,
\] for all \(\mathbf{v},\mathbf{w}\in T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\). In particular, \(\mathscr{F}_1\) is the quadratic form associated to the symmetric bilinear form \(I_{\mathbf{p}}\), that is, \[
\mathscr{F}_1 (\mathbf{v}) = I_{\mathbf{p}} (\mathbf{v},\mathbf{v}) \,, \quad \forall \, \mathbf{v}\in T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\,.
\]



Definition 73With a little abuse of notation, we also denote by \(\mathscr{F}_1\) the \(2 \times 2\) matrix \[
\mathscr{F}_1 :=
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
E & F \\
F & G
\end{array}
\right) \,.
\]



Proposition 74: First fundamental form and reparametrizations
Let \(\mathcal{S}\) be a regular surface and \({\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U \to \mathbb{R}^3\) a regular chart. Suppose that \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}} \colon \widetilde{U} \to \mathbb{R}^3\) is a reparametrization of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\), that is, \[
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}} = {\pmb{\sigma}}\circ \Phi \,,
\] where \(\Phi \colon \widetilde{U} \to U\) is a diffeomorphism. Denote the first fundamental forms of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\) by, respectively, \[\begin{align*}
\mathscr{F}_1 & = E \, du^2 + 2F \, du dv + G \, dv^2 \,, \\
\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}_1 & = \widetilde{E} \, d\tilde{u}^2 + 2 \widetilde{F} \, d\tilde{u} d\tilde{v} + \widetilde{G} \, d\tilde{v}^2 \,.
\end{align*}\]

The matrices of \(\mathscr{F}_1\) and \(\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}_1\) are related by \[
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
\widetilde{E} & \widetilde{F} \\
\widetilde{F} & \widetilde{G}
\end{array}
\right)  
=
(J \Phi)^T \,
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
E & F \\
F & G
\end{array}
\right)
\,
J \Phi  \,,
\tag{3.2}\] where \(J\Phi\) is the Jacobian of \(\Phi\) \[
J\Phi = \left(   
\begin{array}{cc}
\dfrac{\partial u}{\partial \tilde u}  &  \dfrac{\partial u}{\partial \tilde v}  \\
\dfrac{\partial v}{\partial \tilde u}  &  \dfrac{\partial v}{\partial \tilde v}
\end{array}
\right) \,.
\]
The linear maps \(du, dv\) and \(d\tilde{u}, d\tilde{v}\) are related by \[
\begin{aligned}
du & = \frac{\partial u}{\partial \tilde{u}} \, d\tilde{u} + \frac{\partial u}{\partial \tilde{v}} \, d\tilde{v} \\
dv & = \frac{\partial v}{\partial \tilde{u}} \, d\tilde{u} + \frac{\partial v}{\partial \tilde{v}} \, d\tilde{v}
\end{aligned}
\tag{3.3}\]




Example 75: FFF of PlaneQuestion. Let \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q} \in \mathbb{R}^3\), with \(\mathbf{p}\) and \(\mathbf{q}\) orthonormal. Consider the plane with chart \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(u,v) = \mathbf{a} + u \mathbf{p}+ v \mathbf{q} \,, \quad (u,v) \in \mathbb{R}^2 \,.
\] Prove that the first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = du^2 + dv^2 \,.
\]
Solution. We have \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}_u = \mathbf{p}\,, \quad {\pmb{\sigma}}_v = \mathbf{q} \,,
\] and therefore, using that \(\mathbf{p}\) and \(\mathbf{q}\) are orthonormal, \[\begin{align*}
E & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_u \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_u = \left\| \mathbf{p} \right\|^2 = 1 \\
F & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_u \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_v = \mathbf{p}\cdot \mathbf{q} = 0 \\
G & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_v \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_v = \left\| \mathbf{q} \right\|^2 = 1 \\
\end{align*}\] The first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is, therefore \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = E \, du^2 + 2 F\, du \, dv + G \, dv^2 = du^2 + dv^2 \,.  
\]



Example 76: FFF of Plane in polar coordinates
Question. Let \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q} \in \mathbb{R}^3\), with \(\mathbf{p}, \mathbf{q}\) orthonormal. In polar coordinates, the plane is charted by \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(\rho,\theta) = \mathbf{a} + \rho \cos(\theta) \mathbf{p}+ \rho \sin(\theta) \mathbf{q} \,, \quad \rho>0 , \, \theta \in (0,2\pi) \,.
\]

By direct calculation, show that the first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = d\rho^2 + \rho^2 d\theta^2 \,.
\]
The first fundamental form of the plane in cartesian coordinates is \[
{\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1 = du^2 + dv^2 \,.
\] Verify that \[
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
E & F \\
F & G
\end{array}
\right)  
=
(J \Phi)^T \,
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
\widetilde{E}& \widetilde{F}\\
\widetilde{F}& \widetilde{G}
\end{array}
\right)
\,
J \Phi  \,,
\] where \(\Phi\) is the change of variables from polar to cartesian coordinates.

Solution.

Compute \(\mathscr{F}_1\) directly: \[\begin{align*}
{\pmb{\sigma}}_{\rho} & = \cos(\theta)\mathbf{p}+ \sin(\theta) \mathbf{q} \\
{\pmb{\sigma}}_{\theta} & = - \rho \sin(\theta) \mathbf{p}+ \rho \cos(\theta) \mathbf{q}
\end{align*}\] and therefore \[\begin{align*}
E & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_{\rho} \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_{\rho} \\
& = \cos^2(\theta)\left\| \mathbf{p} \right\|^2 + \sin^2(\theta)\left\| \mathbf{q} \right\|^2 + 2 \cos(\theta) \sin(\theta) \mathbf{p}\cdot \mathbf{q} \\
& = 1 \\
F & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_{\rho} \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_{\theta} = 0 \\
G & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_{\theta} \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_{\theta} = r^2 \\
\end{align*}\] Then the first fundamental form is \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = E \, d{\rho}^2 + 2 F\, d{\rho} \, d\theta + G \, d\theta^2 = d{\rho}^2 + {\rho}^2 d\theta^2 \,.  
\]
The change of variables from polar to cartesian coordinates is \[
\Psi({\rho},\theta) = ( {\rho} \cos(\theta), {\rho} \sin (\theta) )\,.
\] The Jacobian of \(\Psi\) is \[
J\Phi = \left(   
\begin{array}{cc}
\cos(\theta) & - {\rho} \sin(\theta)  \\
\sin(\theta)  & {\rho} \cos(\theta)
\end{array}
\right) \,.
\] The matrix of \({\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1\) is just the identity: \[
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
\widetilde{E}& \widetilde{F}\\
\widetilde{F}& \widetilde{G}
\end{array}
\right)
=
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 1
\end{array}
\right) \,.
\] Therefore, we have \[\begin{align*}
(J \Phi)^T &
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
\widetilde{E}& \widetilde{F}\\
\widetilde{F}& \widetilde{G}
\end{array}
\right)
\,
J \Phi
= (J \Phi)^T \, J \Phi \\
&=
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
\cos(\theta) &  \sin(\theta) \\
-\rho \sin(\theta) & \rho \cos(\theta)
\end{array}
\right)
\left(   
\begin{array}{cc}
\cos(\theta) & - \rho \sin(\theta)  \\
\sin(\theta)  & \rho \cos(\theta)
\end{array}
\right) \\
&=
\left(   
\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0  \\
0  & \rho^2  
\end{array}
\right)
=
\left(   
\begin{array}{cc}
E & F  \\
F  & G  
\end{array}
\right) \,.
\end{align*}\]




Example 77: FFF of Unit cylinderQuestion. Consider the unit cylinder with chart \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(u,v) = (\cos(u), \sin(u),  v)  \,, \quad (u,v) \in (0,2\pi) \times \mathbb{R}\,.
\] Prove that the first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = du^2 + dv^2 \,.
\]
Solution. We have \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}_u = (-\sin(u),\cos(u), 0 )  \,, \quad {\pmb{\sigma}}_v = (0,0,1) \,,
\] and therefore \[\begin{align*}
E & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_u \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_u = 1 \\
F & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_u \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_v = 0 \\
G & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_v \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_v = 1 \\
\end{align*}\] Then the first fundamental form is \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = E \, du^2 + 2 F\, du \, dv + G \, dv^2 = du^2 + dv^2 \,.  
\]



Example 78Question. Find the first fundamental form of the surface chart \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(u, v)=\left(u-v, u+v, u^{2}+v^{2}\right)\,.
\]
Solution. We compute \[
\begin{aligned}
{{\pmb{\sigma}}}_{u}& =(1,1,2 u) \\
{{\pmb{\sigma}}}_{v}& =(-1,1,2 v) \\
E & = {{\pmb{\sigma}}}_{u}\cdot {{\pmb{\sigma}}}_{v}= 2\left(1+2 u^{2}\right) \\
F & ={{\pmb{\sigma}}}_{u}\cdot {{\pmb{\sigma}}}_{v}= 4 u v \\
G & = {{\pmb{\sigma}}}_{v}\cdot {{\pmb{\sigma}}}_{v}= \left(1+2 v^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
\] so that \[
\mathscr{F}_{1}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
2\left(1+2 u^{2}\right) & 4 u v \\
4 u v & 2\left(1+2 v^{2}\right)
\end{array}\right) \,.
\]

3.12 Length of curves

Proposition 79
Let \(\mathcal{S}\) be a regular surface with chart \({\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U \to \mathbb{R}^3\). Suppose \[
{\pmb{\gamma}}\colon (a,b) \to {\pmb{\sigma}}(U) \subseteq \mathcal{S}
\] is a smooth curve. Then \[
{\pmb{\gamma}}(t) = {\pmb{\sigma}}(u(t), v(t)) \,,
\] for some smooth functions \(u,v \colon (a,b) \to \mathbb{R}\), and \[
\int_{a}^{b} \left\| \dot{{\pmb{\gamma}}}(t) \right\| \, dt =
\int_{a}^{b} \sqrt{  E \dot{u}^2 + 2F \dot u \dot v + G \dot{v}^2  } \, dt \,,
\] where in the above formula:

\(\dot u, \dot v\) are computed at \(t\),
\(E,F,G\) are computed at \((u(t),v(t))\).




Example 80: Curves on the Cone
Question. Consider the cone with chart \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(u,v)=(\cos(u) v, \sin (u) v, v) \,,
\] where \(u  \in (0,2\pi)\) and \(v >0\). Prove the following:

The first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = 2 \, du^2 + u^2 \, dv^2 \,.
\]
Let \({\pmb{\gamma}}(t):= {\pmb{\sigma}}(t,t)\). The length of \({\pmb{\gamma}}\) is \[
\int_{\pi/2}^{\pi} \left\| \dot{{\pmb{\gamma}}}(t) \right\| \, dt = \int_{\pi/2}^{\pi} \sqrt{ t^2 + 2  } \, dt  \,.
\]

Solution.

We have \[\begin{align*}
{\pmb{\sigma}}_u & = (- \sin(u)v, \cos(u)v,0) \\
{\pmb{\sigma}}_v & = (\cos(u), \sin (u), 1) \\
E & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_u \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_u = v^2 \\
F & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_u \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_v  = 0 \\
G & = {\pmb{\sigma}}_v \cdot {\pmb{\sigma}}_v = 2
\end{align*}\] The first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = v^2 \, du^2 + 2 \, dv^2 \,.
\]
By definition we have \[
{\pmb{\gamma}}(t) = {\pmb{\sigma}}(t,t) \,,
\] so that \[
{\pmb{\gamma}}(t) = {\pmb{\sigma}}(u(t),v(t))
\] with \[
u(t) = t \,, \quad v(t) = t \,.
\] In particular \[
\dot u = 1\,, \quad \dot v = 1
\] and \[\begin{align*}
E(u(t),v(t)) & = E(t,t) = t^2 \\
F(u(t),v(t)) & = F(t,t) = 0 \\
G(u(t),v(t)) & = G(t,t) = 2  \,.
\end{align*}\] Therefore, \[\begin{align*}
\int_{\pi/2}^{\pi} \left\| \dot{{\pmb{\gamma}}}(t) \right\| \, dt & =
\int_{\pi/2}^{\pi} \sqrt{  E \dot{u}^2 + 2F \dot u \dot v + G \dot{v}^2  } \, dt \\
& = \int_{\pi/2}^{\pi} \sqrt{  t^2 + 2   } \, dt   \,.
\end{align*}\]

text:
3.13 Isometries

Definition 81: Local Isometry and Isometry
Let \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be regular surfaces and \[
f \colon \mathcal{S}\to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}
\] be a smooth map. Denote the differential of \(f\) by \[
d_{\mathbf{p}}f \colon T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\to T_{f(\mathbf{p})} \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\,.
\]
We say that:

\(f\) is a local isometry, if for all \(\mathbf{p}\in \mathcal{S}\) \[
\mathbf{v}\cdot \mathbf{w}= d_{\mathbf{p}}f (\mathbf{v}) \cdot d_{\mathbf{p}}f (\mathbf{w}) \,, \quad
\forall \, \mathbf{v}, \mathbf{w}\in T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\,.
\tag{3.4}\] In this case, \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) are said to be locally isometric.
\(f\) is an isometry if:

\(f\) is a local isometry;
\(f\) is a diffeomorphism of \(\mathcal{S}\) into \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\).

In this case, \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) are said to be isometric.




Theorem 82Let \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be regular surfaces and \[
f \colon \mathcal{S}\to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}
\] a local isometry. Then \(f\) is a local diffeomorphims.



Theorem 83
Let \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be regular surfaces and \(f \colon \mathcal{S}\to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be a smooth map. They are equivalent:

\(f\) is a local isometry.
Let \({\pmb{\gamma}}\) be a curve in \(\mathcal{S}\) and consider the curve \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}= f \circ {\pmb{\gamma}}\) on \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\). Then \({\pmb{\gamma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}\) have the same length.




Theorem 84
Let \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be regular surfaces and \(f \colon \mathcal{S}\to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be a local diffeomorphism. They are equivalent:

\(f\) is a local isometry.
Let \({\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U \to \mathcal{S}\) be a regular chart of \(\mathcal{S}\) and consider the chart of \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) given by
\[
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}} \colon U \to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}} \,, \qquad
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}} = f \circ {\pmb{\sigma}}\,.
\] Then \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\) have the same first fundamental form, that is, \[
E = \widetilde{E} \,, \quad F = \widetilde{F} \,, \quad G = \widetilde{G} \,.
\]




Theorem 85
Let \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be regular surfaces and consider charts \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U \to \mathcal{S}\,, \qquad
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\colon U \to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\,.
\] Assume that \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\) have the same first fundamental form: \[
E = \widetilde{E} \,, \quad F = \widetilde{F} \,, \quad G = \widetilde{G} \,.
\] We have:

The surfaces \({\pmb{\sigma}}(U)\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) are locally isometric.
A local isometry is given by \[
f \colon {\pmb{\sigma}}(U) \to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\,, \qquad
f = \widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\circ {\pmb{\sigma}}^{-1} \,.
\]




Example 86: Plane and Cylinder are locally isometric
Question. Consider the plane \[
\mathcal{S}= \{ (x,y,z) \in \mathbb{R}^3   \, \colon \, x = 0  \} \,,
\] and the unit cylinder \[
\mathcal{S}= \{ (x,y,z) \in \mathbb{R}^3 \, \colon \,  x^2 + y^2 = 1 \} \,.
\] Define the function \[
f \colon \mathcal{S}\to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\,, \qquad f(0,y,z) = (\cos(y),\sin(y),z) \,.
\]

Prove that \(f\) is smooth.
Prove that \(f\) is a local isometry.

Note: This shows that the Plane and the Cylinder are locally isometric.
Solution.

Note that \(f \in \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) because \[
\cos(y)^2 + \sin(y)^2 = 1\,,
\] therefore \(f\) is well-defined. Moreover, \(f\) is the restriction to \(\mathcal{S}\) of the function \[
g \colon \mathbb{R}^3 \to \mathbb{R}^3 \,, \qquad g(x,y,z) = (\cos(y),\sin(y),z) \,.
\] Since \(g\) is smooth, and \(g(\mathcal{S}) = \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\), by Theorem 37 we infer that \(g |_{\mathcal{S}} = f\) is smooth between \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\).
Define the chart of \(\mathcal{S}\): \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(u,v) = (0,u,v) \,, \quad u,v \in \mathbb{R}\,.
\] We already know that \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is regular, with first fundamental form coefficients given by \[
E = 1 \,, \quad F = 1 \,, \quad G = 1 \,,
\] and corresponding first fundamental form \[
{\mathscr{F}}_1 = du^2 + dv^2 \,.
\] Define \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}= f \circ {\pmb{\sigma}}\). Therefore, \[
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}(u,v) = f(0,u,v) = (\cos(u),\sin(u),v) \,.
\] We have that \[\begin{align*}
{\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{u}& = ( -\sin(u),\cos(u),0 ) \\
{\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{v}& = (0,0,1) \\
\widetilde{E}& = {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{u}\cdot {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{u}= 1 \\  
\widetilde{F}& = {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{u}\cdot {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{v}= 0 \\
\widetilde{G}& = {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{v}\cdot {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{v}= 1
\end{align*}\] Therefore, the first fundamental form of \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}= f \circ {\pmb{\sigma}}\) is \[
{\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1 =  du^2 + dv^2 \,.
\] In particular, we have shown that \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\) have the same first fundamental form: \[
{\mathscr{F}}_1 = {\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1 \,.
\] Since \(\mathcal{A} = \{{\pmb{\sigma}}\}\) is an atlas for \(\mathcal{S}\), by Theorem 85 we conclude that \(f\) is a local isometry of \(\mathcal{S}\) into \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\).




Example 87: Plane and Cone are locally isometric
Question. Consider the cone without tip \[
\mathcal{S}= \{ (x,y,z) \in \mathbb{R}^3 \, \colon \, x^2 + y^2 = z^2 \,, \,\, z > 0 \} \,,
\] and the plane \[
\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}= \{ (x,y,z)\in \mathbb{R}^3 \, \colon \, z = 0 \} \,.
\]

Let \({\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U \to \mathcal{S}\) be the chart of the Cone \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(\rho,\theta) = (\rho \cos(\theta), \rho \sin(\theta), \rho ) \,,
\] where we define \[
U:= \left\{ (\rho,\theta) \in \mathbb{R}^2 \, \colon \, \rho > 0 , \, \theta \in (0,2\pi) \right\} \,.
\] Compute the first fundamental form \({\mathscr{F}}_1\) of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\).
Let \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\colon U \to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be the chart of the Plane \[
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}(\rho,\theta) = (a\rho \cos(b\theta), a\rho \sin(b\theta), 0 )
\] where \(a>0\) and \(b \in (0,1]\) are constants. Compute the first fundamental form \({\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1\) of \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\).
Find coefficients \(a,b\) such that \[
{\mathscr{F}}_1 = {\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1 \,.
\]
Conclude that \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) are locally isometric.

Solution.

We have already computed in Example 81, that the first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is \[
{\mathscr{F}}_1 = 2 d\rho^2 + \rho^2 d\theta^2 \,.
\]
First of all, note that \[
\theta \in (0,2\pi), \quad b \in (0,1] \quad \implies \quad
b \theta \in (0,2\pi) \,,
\] showing that \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\) is well defined for all \((\rho,\theta) \in U\). We compute \[\begin{align*}
{\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{\rho} & = ( a \cos(b\theta), a \sin(b\theta), 0 ) \\
{\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{\theta} & = ( - ab \rho \sin(b \theta), ab\rho \cos(b\theta), 0 ) \\
\widetilde{E}& = {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{\rho} \cdot {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{\rho} = a^2 \\  
\widetilde{F}& = {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{\rho} \cdot {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{\theta} = 0 \\
\widetilde{G}& = {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{\theta} \cdot {\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}}_{\theta} = a^2b^2 \rho^2
\end{align*}\] from which we conclude that the first fundamental form of \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\) is \[
{\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1 = a^2 d\rho^2 + a^2b^2 \rho^2 d\rho^2 \,.
\]
Equating \({\mathscr{F}}_1\) and \({\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1\) we obtain \[
a^2 = 2 , \,\, a^2b^2 = 1 \quad \implies \quad a = \sqrt{2} \,, \,\, b = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \,.
\] Note that \(a>0\) and \(0<b<1\), showing that \(a,b\) are admissible.
For \(a = \sqrt{2}\) and \(b = 1/\sqrt{2}\) we have that \[
{\mathscr{F}}_1 = {\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1 \,.
\] Since \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\) are regular charts for \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\), respectively, from Theorem 84 we conclude that \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) are locally isometric. Furthermore, the local isometry is given by \[
f \colon \mathcal{S}\to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\,, \qquad f = \widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\circ {\pmb{\sigma}}^{-1} \,.
\]

3.14 Angles between curves

Definition 88: Angle between curvesLet \(\mathcal{S}\) be a regular surface. Let \({\pmb{\gamma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}\) be curves on \(\mathcal{S}\) such that \[
{\pmb{\gamma}}(t_0) = \mathbf{p}= \widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}( t_0 ) \,.
\] The angle \(\theta\) between \({\pmb{\gamma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}\) is \[
\cos(\theta) = \frac{ \dot{{\pmb{\gamma}}}\cdot \dot{\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}}}{ \| \dot{{\pmb{\gamma}}}\| \,  \| \dot{\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}}\| } \,,
\] where \(\dot{{\pmb{\gamma}}}\) and \(\dot{\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}}\) are evaluated at \(t_0\).



Theorem 89Let \(\mathcal{S}\) be a regular surface, \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) a regular chart at \(\mathbf{p}\), and \({\pmb{\gamma}},\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}\) smooth curves on \(\mathcal{S}\) such that \[
{\pmb{\gamma}}(t_0) = \mathbf{p}= \widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}( t_0 )  \,.
\] There exist smooth functions \(u,v,\tilde{u},\tilde{v}\) such that \[
{\pmb{\gamma}}(t) = {\pmb{\sigma}}(u(t),v(t)) \,, \quad
\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}(t) = {\pmb{\sigma}}(\tilde{u}(t),\tilde{v}(t)) \,.
\] The angle between \({\pmb{\gamma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}\) is \[
\cos(\theta) = \frac{ E  \dot u \dot{\tilde u} + F ( \dot u \dot{\tilde v}+ \dot{\tilde{u}} \dot v) + G \dot v \dot{\tilde v} }{ (E  \dot{u}^2 + 2 F  \dot u \dot v + G \dot{v}^2 )^{1/2} (E  \dot{\tilde{u}}^2 + 2 F  \dot{\tilde{u}} \dot{\tilde{v}} + G \dot{\tilde{v}}^2 )^{1/2} } \,,
\] where \(E,F,G,\widetilde{E},\widetilde{F},\widetilde{G}\) are evaluated at \((u(t_0),v(t_0))\) and \(\dot{u},\dot{v}, \dot{\widetilde{u}}, \dot{\widetilde{v}}\) are evaluated at \(t_0\).



Example 90
Question. Let \(S\) be a surface with surface chart \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(u, v) = \left(u, v, e^{u v}\right) \,.
\]

Calculate its first fundamental form.
Calculate \(\cos (\theta)\) where \(\theta\) is the angle between the two curves \[\begin{align*}
{\pmb{\gamma}}(t) & ={\pmb{\sigma}}(u(t), v(t)), \quad u(t)=t,\, v(t)=t \,, \\
\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}(t) & = {\pmb{\sigma}}( \tilde{u}(t),\tilde{v}(t) ) \,, \quad \tilde{u}(t) = 1 , \, \tilde{v}(t) = t \,.
\end{align*}\]

Solution.

We calculate \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}_u = \left(1,0, e^{u v} v\right), \quad {\pmb{\sigma}}_v=\left(0,1, e^{u v} u\right) \,.
\] Therefore, the coefficients of the first fundamental form are \[\begin{align*}
E(u,v) & =1+e^{2 u v} v^2 \\
F(u,v) & = e^{2 u v} u v \\
G(u,v) & = 1+e^{2 u v} u^2
\end{align*}\]
The curves \({\pmb{\gamma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}\) intersect at \[
{\pmb{\gamma}}(1)=\widetilde{{\pmb{\gamma}}}(1)={\pmb{\sigma}}(1,1) \,.
\] We calculate \[
\dot{u}(1)=1, \quad \dot{v}(1)=1, \quad \dot{\tilde{u}}(1)=0, \quad \dot{\tilde{v}}(1) = 1 \,,
\] and \[\begin{align*}
E(1,1) & = 1+e^2 \\
F(1,1) & =e^2 \\
G(1,1) & =1+e^2
\end{align*}\] Therefore \[
\begin{aligned}
\cos \theta & =\frac{E \dot{u} \dot{\tilde{u}} + F \left(\dot{u} \dot{\tilde{v}}+ \dot{\tilde{u}}  \dot{v}\right)+G \dot{v} \dot{\tilde{v}}}{\sqrt{E \dot{u}^2 + 2 F \dot{u} \dot{v} + G \dot{v}^2} \sqrt{E \dot{\tilde{u}}^2 + 2 F\dot{\tilde{u}} \dot{\tilde{v}}+ G \dot{\tilde{v}}^2}} \\
& =\frac{1+2 e^2}{\sqrt{2+4 e^2} \sqrt{1+e^2}}=\sqrt{\frac{1+2 e^2}{2+2 e^2}} \,.
\end{aligned}
\]

title: 3  Surfaces
text:
3.15 Conformal maps

Definition 91: Conformal mapLet \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be regular surfaces, and \[
f \colon \mathcal{S}\to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}
\] a local diffeomorphism. We say that \(f\) is a conformal map if for all \(\mathbf{p}\in \mathcal{S}\) and \(\mathbf{v}, \mathbf{w}\in T_{\mathbf{p}} \mathcal{S}\) is holds \[
\theta = \widetilde{\theta} \,,
\] where:

\(\theta\) is the angle between \(\mathbf{v}\) and \(\mathbf{w}\),
\(\widetilde{\theta}\) is the angle between \(d_{\mathbf{p}} f(\mathbf{v})\) and \(d_{\mathbf{p}} f(\mathbf{w})\).

In this case, we say that \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) are conformal.



Proposition 92Let \(f\) be a local isometry. Then \(f\) is a conformal map.



Theorem 93
Let \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be regular surfaces and \(f \colon \mathcal{S}\to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be a local diffeomorphism. They are equivalent:

\(f\) is a conformal map.
Let \({\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U \to \mathcal{S}\) be a regular chart of \(\mathcal{S}\) and consider the chart of \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) given by \[
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}  \colon U \to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}} \,, \qquad \widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}} = f \circ {\pmb{\sigma}}\,.
\] Then, there exists \(\lambda \colon U \to \mathbb{R}\) such that \[
\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}_1 = \lambda (u,v) \mathscr{F}_1 \,, \quad \forall \, (u,v) \in U \,,
\] where \(\mathscr{F}_1\) and \(\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}_1\) are the first fundamental forms of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\), respectively.




Theorem 94
Let \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be regular surfaces and consider charts \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U \to \mathcal{S}\,, \qquad
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\colon U \to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\,.
\] Assume there exists \(\lambda \colon U \to \mathbb{R}\) such that \[
\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}_1 = \lambda (u,v) \mathscr{F}_1 \,, \quad \forall \, (u,v) \in U \,,
\] where \(\mathscr{F}_1\) and \(\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}_1\) are the first fundamental forms of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\), respectively. We have:

The surfaces \({\pmb{\sigma}}(U)\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) are conformal.
A conformal map is given by \[
f \colon {\pmb{\sigma}}(U) \to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\,, \qquad
f = \widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\circ {\pmb{\sigma}}^{-1} \,.
\]




Example 95: Stereographic Projection
Question. Denote the unit sphere by \[
\mathbb{S}^2 = \{ (x,y,z) \in \mathbb{R}^3 \, \colon \, x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 1 \} \,,
\] and consider the surface \[
\mathcal{S}= \mathbb{S}^2 \smallsetminus \{N\} \,,
\] where the point \(N = (0,0,1)\) is the North Pole. Denote the plane \(\{z = 0\}\) by \[
\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}= \{ (x,y,z) \in \mathbb{R}^3 \, \colon \, z = 0 \} \,,
\] The plane \(\{z=0\}\) slices through the equator of the sphere. Let \(P=(x,y,z)\) be any point on \(\mathbb{S}^2\) except the north pole. The line joining the north pole to \(P\) intersects the plane \(\{z=0\}\) at the point \(P'\). The point \(P'\) defines the Stereographic Projection map, which is easily computed to be: \[
f \colon \mathcal{S}\to \widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\,, \quad
f(x,y,z) = \left( \frac{x}{1-z},\frac{y}{1-z},0  \right) \,.
\] Prove that:

\(f\) is a conformal map.
\(f\) is not a local isometry.

Note: In particular, the Sphere and the Plane are conformal.
Solution. It is not difficult to prove that \(f\) is invertible, with inverse given by \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(u,v) =\left( \frac{2u}{u^2+v^2+1},  \frac{2v}{u^2+v^2+1} , 1-\frac{2}{u^2+v^2+1}\right) \,.
\] We have that \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is a regular chart for \(\mathcal{S}\), forming an altas of one chart. It is straightforward to compute that the coefficients of the first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) are \[
E = G = \lambda(u,v) := \frac{4}{(u^2+v^2+1)^2} \,, \qquad F = 0 \,.
\] In particualar the fisrt fundamental form is \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = \lambda(u,v) (du^2 + dv^2) \,.
\] Define the chart of \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\): \[
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}= f \circ {\pmb{\sigma}}\,.
\] Since \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is the inverse of \(f\), we have that \[
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}(u,v) = (u,v,0) \,.
\] As already computed, the first fundamental form of \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\) is \[
{\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1 = du^2 + dv^2 \,.
\] We can now conclude:

We have that \[
{\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1 = \frac{1}{\lambda} {\mathscr{F}}_1  \,.
\] Since \(\mathcal{A} = \{{\pmb{\sigma}}\}\) is an atlas for \(\mathcal{S}\), by Theorem 93 we conclude that \(f\) is a conformal map.
Since \({\lambda}\) is not always equal to \(1\), we have that \[
{\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}}_1 \neq {\mathscr{F}}_1 \,.
\] Therefore, by Theorem 84, we conclude that \(f\) cannot be a local isometry.




Example 96: Sphere and Plane are conformal
Question. Let \(\mathcal{S}\) be the plane \(\{z=0\}\) with chart \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}(u,v) := (u,v,0) \,, \quad u,v \in \mathbb{R}\,.
\] Let \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) be the sphere \(\mathbb{S}^2\) with parametrization \[
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}(u,v) := \left(  \cos(u) \mathop{\mathrm{sech}}(v), \sin(u) \mathop{\mathrm{sech}}(v) , \tanh (v) \right) \,.
\]

Compute the first fundamental forms of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) and \(\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}\).
Show that \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) are conformal.

Solution.

As already computed, the first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = du^2 + dv^2 \,.
\] Using the identitities \[\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dv} \left( \mathop{\mathrm{sech}}(v)  \right) & = - \mathop{\mathrm{sech}}(v) \tanh (v) \,, \\
\frac{d}{dv} \left( \tanh (v) \right)  & = {\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2 (v) \,,
\end{align*}\] we obtain \[\begin{align*}
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}_u & = ( -\sin(u) \mathop{\mathrm{sech}}(v) , \cos(u)\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}(v) , 0 )  \\
\widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}_v & = ( -\cos(v) \mathop{\mathrm{sech}}(v) \tanh(v) , -\sin(u) \mathop{\mathrm{sech}}(v) \tanh(v) , {\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2(v) )
\end{align*}\] By recalling that \[
{\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2 (v) + {\tanh}^2 (v) = 1 \,,
\] we compute \[\begin{align*}
\widetilde{E} & = \widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}_u \cdot \widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}_u = {\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2(v) (\cos^2(u) + \sin^2(u)) = {\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2(v)  \\
\widetilde{F} & = \widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}_u \cdot \widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}_v =  0 \\
\widetilde{G} & = \widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}_v \cdot \widetilde{{\pmb{\sigma}}}_v = {\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2(v) ({\tanh}^2(v) + {\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2(v)) = {\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2(v) \\
\end{align*}\] Hence the first fundamental form of \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) is \[
\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}_1 = {\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2(v) \, \left(  du^2 + dv^2 \right) \,.
\]
We have computed that \[
\widetilde{\mathscr{F}}_1 =  {\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2(v) \, \left(  du^2 + dv^2 \right) =  {\mathop{\mathrm{sech}}}^2(v) \,\mathscr{F}_1 \,.
\] Since \(A = \{{\pmb{\sigma}}\}\) is an atlas for \(\mathcal{S}\), by Theorem 94 we conclude that \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\widetilde{\mathcal{S}}\) are conformal.

3.16 Conformal parametrizations

Definition 97: Conformal parametrizationLet \(\mathcal{S}\) be a regular surface and \[
{\pmb{\sigma}}\colon U  \to  \mathcal{S}
\] be a regular chart of \(\mathcal{S}\). We say that \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) is a conformal parametrization if the first fundamental form of \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) satisfies \[
\mathscr{F}_1 = \lambda(u,v)  ( du^2 +  dv^2)
\] for some function \(\lambda \colon U \to \mathbb{R}\).



Theorem 98A conformal parametrization \({\pmb{\sigma}}\) preserves angles between vectors. Specifically, let \({\pmb{\gamma}}_{1}(t), {\pmb{\gamma}}_{2}(t)\) be curves in \(\mathbb{R}^{2}\) such that \({\dot{{\pmb{\gamma}}}}_{1}\left(t_{0}\right), {\dot{{\pmb{\gamma}}}}_{2}\left(t_{0}\right)\) make angle \(\theta\). If \[
{\pmb{\gamma}}_{3}(t)={\pmb{\sigma}}\left({\pmb{\gamma}}_{1}(t)\right),  \qquad {\pmb{\gamma}}_{4}(t)={\pmb{\sigma}}\left({\pmb{\gamma}}_{2}(t)\right) \,,
\] then \({\dot{{\pmb{\gamma}}}}_{3}\left(t_{0}\right), {\dot{{\pmb{\gamma}}}}_{4}\left(t_{0}\right)\) also make angle \(\theta\).
